comments.htmlContent:
A PR being in the "closed" state makes it sound like the commits on the PR were never merged. I can understand that we don't want to mark unmergeable¬†PRs "merged", but maybe we could still add a comment to the closed PR's timeline saying something like "the commits that appear on this PR were merged to `main` as part of another PR (#1234)" (or, in the general case, "‚Ä¶as part of other PRs (#1234, #5678, #9012)"). It would help users understand why they find those commits in `main` despite the PR that they are looking at having been closed and never having been approved.
In fact, the same annotation might be useful if the commits that were on a PR that was already closed get merged via a different PR.
comments.content:
A PR being in the "closed" state makes it sound like the commits on the PR were never merged. I can understand that we don't want to mark unmergeable¬†PRs "merged", but maybe we could still add a comment to the closed PR's timeline saying something like "the commits that appear on this PR were merged to `main` as part of another PR (#1234)" (or, in the general case, "‚Ä¶as part of other PRs (#1234, #5678, #9012)"). It would help users understand why they find those commits in `main` despite the PR that they are looking at having been closed and never having been approved.
In fact, the same annotation might be useful if the commits that were on a PR that was _already_ closed get merged via a different PR.

quotedFileContent.value:
Breaking this association is also trivial.
Any change to any topic branch (including clicking the ‚Äúupdate branch‚Äù button) will cause it to point to a different sha and thus extract itself from its previous network.

replies.htmlContent:
The issue is that when they first create their topic branch, they'll be pointing at the current HEAD of the main branch.

The second developer in this scenario would be able to create a topic branch, but unable¬†to open a new PR for it. This would happen essentially at random times, which isn't a great user¬†experience.

we have since discovered that this flow is blocked by the PR ux for the trivial, no new commit cases. You must have at least one commit different from the base branch to open a PR.¬†
However, this commit can still be identical to another developers commit on another branch, see the example setup at the top¬†of this doc.

comments.htmlContent:
Curious if we have any sense of how many customers rely on the existing behavior, where PR2 would not be mergeable.¬†

Personally, I agree with the recommended proposal here, but might be helpful to get a heads up on how many frustrated customers we might be facing after making this change.¬†

I can foresee plenty of folks being peeved that previously "blocked" bugs are now allowed to be merged (even though I agree, our platform shouldn't be the thing that determines which review is more "valid" than the other in this scenario).

replies.htmlContent:
I'm guessing the current design grew out of GitHub's propensity to be commit-centric in matters where all the other git providers are PR-centric.

Also, when pushing from the command line it's a bit more work to loop through all possible pull requests and evaluate each one¬†individually,¬†than it is to just fetch all the approvals and count them.
replies.content:
I'm guessing the current design grew out of GitHub's propensity to be commit-centric in matters where all the other git providers are PR-centric.

Also, when pushing from the command line it's a bit more work to loop through all possible pull requests and evaluate each one¬†individually,¬†than it is to just fetch all the approvals and count them.

replies.htmlContent:
@jeschu1@github.com¬†

Yes, last pusher is where this "treat these 3 pull request¬†like they're one PR" falls apart.

The problem is that you push to a branch, and each PR has its own branch. We don't let you make multiple pull requests from A to B. So there's no clearly¬†defined "last pusher", there is a different answer for each pull request.

comments.htmlContent:
Worth pointing out that in the case of the Required Approval and Discussion Resolution, the PR is a clear artifact.¬†

For Approvals we clearly say who approved what and where.¬†

Discussions of courses¬†requires comments in all PRs to be resolved.

Last Pusher however, does have a gap here.

replies.htmlContent: It's a tri-state thing: a PR can be open (green), closed (red), or merged (purple).
replies.content: It's a tri-state thing: a PR can be open (green), closed (red), or merged (purple).

replies.htmlContent: So to actually answer your question, a PR whose branch "merges out from under you" will get marked as merged in the current system, and will continue to do so under the new proposed system, unless we made some effort to avoid that (which would be non-trivial ‚Äî¬†it detects mergedness based on ahead/behind status, and it has operated that way for many years AFAIK).
replies.content: So to actually answer your question, a PR whose branch "merges out from under you" will get marked as _merged_ in the current system, and will continue to do so under the new proposed system, unless we made some effort to avoid that (which would be non-trivial ‚Äî¬†it detects mergedness based on ahead/behind status, and it has operated that way for many years AFAIK).

replies.htmlContent: I can't speak to how far back this might go @darylcantrell@github.com but it is a looong time (predates my arrival at GitHub by some margin, for sure, and that was in mid-2021). comments.htmlContent: Whoa, what does it mean for a PR to be unmerged even though its commits have all, in fact, been merged to its target branch? We already merged that for you a week ago!" It seems like the entrance to a topsy-turvy world.

replies.htmlContent:
Today, if there are multiple equivalent PRs, then if one has fulfilled all its requirements then all of the equivalent PRs must also be fulfilled (because anything blocking one would be shared with the others). So, if one is mergeable, pushing a merge commit would close all of the equivalent PRs with the merge commit generated via the command line.¬†

But let's say somehow we had one in a mergeable state and one blocked (not sure if this is possible, but maybe 1 required status check is goofed up and blocking one of the equivalent prs), then I believe pushing a merge commit would be blocked.

@darylcantrell@github.com correct me if I'm wrong

This is an edge case, but using similar logic to point 1.1, we allow merging any PR in an approved state, regardless of of how many are not in an approved state.¬†

The main idea here is that we no longer aggregate anything.
replies.content:
This is an edge case, but using similar logic to point 1.1, we allow merging any PR in an approved state, regardless of of how many are not in an approved state.¬†

The main idea here is that we no longer aggregate anything.

quotedFileContent.value:
Command line merges will close at most a single PR
If a branch is merged while equivalent PRs are not mergeable, the unfulfilled PRs will stay open.
If multiple equivalent PRs are mergeable, only the one chosen to generate the merge commit message (and therefore linked to the commit) is closed.

replies.htmlContent:
We look through all of them and see if any PRs are fully "green".

I would argue that we should store the final merge commit with the PRs which are green, but not those which are not passing. This lets the user follow the link from the commit to a passing PR, which is a good auditing experience.
